author: By Alan Feuer and Adam Goldman
title: Federal Agents Seized Phone of John Eastman, Key Figure in Jan. 6 Plan
description: The action suggests that the criminal inquiry is accelerating into the efforts to help overturn the results of the 2020 election.
content: Federal agents armed with a search warrant have seized the phone of John Eastman, a lawyer who advised former President Donald J. Trump on key elements of the effort to overturn the results of the 2020 election, according to a court filing by Mr. Eastman on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: Redesign Around Notre-Dame to Keep Tourists Moving and Lower Temperatures
description: Plans call for more trees around the famed Paris cathedral, which is being rebuilt after a devastating 2019 fire, and for a cooling system in front of the building.
content: PARIS — An overhaul of the area around Notre-Dame Cathedral in Paris will open it up toward the Seine River and help millions of visitors flow through more easily while also mitigating the effects of climate change, city officials said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: June 27, 2022
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, June 27, 2022.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Darra Goldstein Illuminates ‘A Brief History of Russian Food’
description: The professor at Williams College starts a millennium or so ago and goes almost to the present.
content: Darra Goldstein’s new Russian history book, “The Kingdom of Rye,” is a useful tool for understanding the country and its people. The author of this slender volume, a professor of Russian at Williams College, starts a millennium or so ago and goes almost to the present, describing the land, climate and rulers of the sprawling nation that often seems just a loaf away from famine. It has four chapters, no recipes but many literary references. Traditional staple foods, especially fermented, cultured, cured, salted, dried, soured and frozen items, are explained. Soaked oats produced a kind of oat milk “more than a thousand years before it became trendy in Brooklyn,” she writes. Russian salad, Russian table service with sequential courses that supplanted service à la française, and caviar, are of genuine Russian origin; vodka is not, though it was rapidly embraced. Even the Russian restaurateur Andrey Dellos, who briefly opened Brasserie Pushkin and Manon in New York, gets a shout-out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Amtrak Train Strikes Car at California Crossing, Killing 3
description: The railroad crossing, on a dirt road without guardrails or a signal, sees a yearly average of one or two accidents, the authorities said.
content: An Amtrak passenger train crashed into a four-door sedan at a crossing without a train signal or guardrails in a rural area of the East Bay in Northern California on Sunday, killing three people and critically injuring two others including a child, a spokesman for the local fire department and emergency services said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Are Updated Booster Shots Coming?
description: The F.D.A. may target fall boosters to Omicron or subvariants.
content: Tomorrow will be a big day for the future of U.S. coronavirus vaccines: A panel of independent advisers to the F.D.A. will recommend whether to update the existing vaccines to take aim at a version of the virus in the Omicron family.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina and Michael Levenson
title: Amtrak Train Hits Truck in Missouri, Killing 3 and Injuring Dozens
description: Amtrak said more than 200 passengers were on the train when it hit a dump truck at a crossing with no lights in Mendon, Mo., causing several cars to derail.
content: An Amtrak train carrying more than 200 passengers crashed into a dump truck in rural Missouri on Monday, killing three people and injuring dozens, the authorities said. It was the second fatal accident involving the railroad service in two days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays
title: New York City’s Noncitizen Voting Law Is Struck Down
description: A State Supreme Court judge from Staten Island said the measure, which would have allowed more than 800,000 noncitizens to vote, violated the State Constitution.
content: A law that would have allowed noncitizens to vote in local elections in New York City was struck down on Monday by a State Supreme Court justice on Staten Island who said it violated the State Constitution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Mitch McConnell’s Court Delivers
description: While Democrats seethe, the Senate Republican leader sees the fruits of his efforts to install an aggressive conservative majority on the Supreme Court.
content: WASHINGTON — When Speaker Nancy Pelosi refers to the Supreme Court as the “Trump-McConnell” court, she does not mean it as a compliment. Senator Mitch McConnell will take it as one anyway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: Returning to the Scene
description: “Only Murders in the Building” is the latest series to explore the mystery: Does a good first season always need a sequel?
content: Early in the second season of Hulu’s “Only Murders in the Building,” Charles-Haden Savage (Steve Martin), one of a trio of amateur sleuths and podcasters, points out a pitfall of murder shows. “It’s very rare for a true-crime podcast to do a sequel,” he says. “They usually move on to a new case that never hits like the original.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: The Politicization of the Supreme Court Is Eroding Its Legitimacy
description: That’s a scary situation for American democracy.
content: “Legitimacy is for losers,” a political scientist once said. It’s a profound concept. The winning side in a decision will gladly accept it without asking why. But the losing side — whether the decision is made by a basketball referee or the Supreme Court — will accept defeat only if they believe the decision was made fairly and by the book.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nipun Prabhakar
title: Documenting India’s Distinctive Birdhouses
description: For seven years, a photographer based in Delhi has collected images of ornamental structures known as chabutras. Here are some of his favorites.
content: Some years ago, while exploring Bhuj, a small city in Gujarat, India’s westernmost state, I stumbled upon a beautiful and initially enigmatic structure: a column that supported an enclosure adorned with hundreds of holes. It seemed to me to be a geometric abstraction of a giant tree — until a pigeon peeped out from one of the openings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: Once an ‘Easy Way Out’ for Equality, Women’s Soccer Is Now a U.S. Force
description: After Title IX passed in 1972, administrators found soccer to be a cheap way to comply. Participation rates for girls and women soared in high schools, universities and club teams.
content: Brooke Volza and the other girls who play in the top division of high school soccer in Albuquerque know all about the Metro Curse: The team that wins the city’s metro tournament at the start of the season is doomed to end the year without a state championship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: MONDAY — Administrative note: We have started offering Spelling Bee stats to our subscribers. Check out your rank from last week and see how you can improve this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Coho Salmon Hatched in New York State
description: The fish are raised in the Finger Lakes region by LocalCoho in an indoor facility established in 2017.
content: Back when salmon were running in rivers and seas on the East Coast, salmon dinners were a New England July Fourth tradition. Wild Atlantic salmon have been pretty much gone for about 75 years, but newly farmed coho from upstate New York are ready to sear or poach and serve traditionally with peas for the upcoming holiday. It’s one of three main Pacific salmon varieties, after king (a.k.a. Chinook) and sockeye. These fish are raised in the Finger Lakes region of New York by LocalCoho, in Auburn, N.Y., in an indoor facility established in 2017 using Recirculated Aquaculture Systems technology supported by private funding. The first fish were harvested in 2019 and now, with a $500,000 grant from New York State Development, they’re expanding from limited wholesale availability to retail. The brilliantly bright reddish-pink flesh of the fish, similar to arctic char, has a silky texture and a flavor that’s milder than sockeye or king.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: U.S. officials say the G7 is close to an agreement on price caps on Russian oil.
description: KRUN, Germany — Leaders of the Group of 7 nations are close to an agreement in principle to begin the process of potentially imposing price caps on Russian oil and are set to impose other new economic penalties on Moscow to support Ukraine, Biden administration officials said on Monday.
content: KRUN, Germany — Leaders of the Group of 7 nations are close to an agreement in principle to begin the process of potentially imposing price caps on Russian oil and are set to impose other new economic penalties on Moscow to support Ukraine, Biden administration officials said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Felice Belman
title: Georgia awaits a court ruling on a six-week abortion ban.
description: The state passed one of the most restrictive abortion laws in the country in 2019. But it has never been enforced, pending court decisions.
content: In 2019, Gov. Brian Kemp of Georgia signed one of the most restrictive abortion laws in the country, effectively outlawing the procedure after six weeks of pregnancy. But the measure has never been enforced. That could soon change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Phyllida Jay
title: Can a Shirt Made in India Beat Savile Row?
description: 100Hands, a luxury shirtmaker, is betting the answer is yes.
content: PUNJAB, India — Sunita Devi, an embroiderer at 100Hands, was working on a shirt, her stitching so beautiful that it prompted a compliment from this reporter. Ms. Devi acknowledged it with a smile, before turning her attention back to the task at hand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: The end of Roe v. Wade.
content: A Supreme Court ruling on Friday that overturned the constitutional right to abortion has unleashed a frenzy of activity. Anti-abortion forces plan to push for near-total bans in every state in the U.S., while abortion rights groups have vowed to fight back in the courts and push the Biden administration to do more to protect abortion rights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Here’s how companies are reacting to the Supreme Court decision on abortion.
description: Even as more companies have become outspoken on social causes, the reaction by corporate America on Friday after the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade was relatively muted.
content: Even as more companies have become outspoken on social causes, the reaction by corporate America on Friday after the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade was relatively muted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: Colorado Avalanche Unseat Tampa Bay to Win the Stanley Cup
description: The Avalanche took the lead in the second period to win their first title since 2001 and end the Lightning’s bid for a third consecutive title. They did it convincingly, never facing elimination.
content: TAMPA, Fla. — Ten teams over the last three years have attempted to eliminate the Tampa Bay Lightning in the postseason as they pursued a dynasty. They tried in the 2020 bubble, they tried in Canada,  across the state of Florida and on the islands of New York, but they all failed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Rosman and Gina Cherelus
title: Women on Why They’re Stocking Up on the Morning-After Pill
description: Sales of the emergency contraceptive surged after the Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: In California, a Republican congressman who voted to impeach Trump survives his primary.
description: Representative David Valadao defeated two Republican primary challengers, in a Central Valley district that now leans Democratic.
content: Representative David Valadao, a Republican running in a strongly Democratic district in California’s Central Valley, will face off in November with his strongest challenger yet after primary voters gave the Republican and Democratic establishments the candidates they wanted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘Sway'
title: ‘Venture Capitalists Are Going to Turn Into Vulture Capitalists,’ and Other Predictions From Andrew Ross Sorkin
description: The New York Times DealBook editor and Kara Swisher try to make sense of the economy.
content: Stocks tumbling, inflation soaring and interest rates climbing — it’s clear America’s economy has hit some turbulence. And yet President Biden says a recession is “not inevitable.” Andrew Ross Sorkin, the founder and editor at large of DealBook at The New York Times, sat down with Kara Swisher to unpack our economic woes, predict what happens next and diagnose what Washington could have done differently.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere
title: F.D.A. May Move Toward Updating Vaccines
description: Scientists had high hopes for a new coronavirus vaccine that combines the existing formulation with one targeting Omicron, but many are not impressed by the results.
content: WASHINGTON — A panel of independent experts advising the Food and Drug Administration is set to recommend on Tuesday whether to update existing Covid-19 vaccines to target a newer version of the coronavirus in a booster shot that Americans could get in the fall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: In This Story Collection, the Dead Are Served Up Hot-Pot Style
description: Sayaka Murata’s “Life Ceremony” explores the grotesque and the intersections of extremes.
content: The Japanese writer Sayaka Murata is best known for “Convenience Store Woman,” her 2016 novel about Keiko, a friendless woman who, to tamp down her darker impulses, devotes her life to a job as an anonymous cashier in a Tokyo food mart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: These Companies Will Cover Travel Expenses for Employee Abortions
description: Dozens of companies have committed to helping their employees get access to reproductive care.
content: After the Supreme Court’s ruling on Friday that ended federal abortion rights, several companies released statements reaffirming their commitment to helping employees gain access to health care services they may not be able to obtain in their state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin
title: Alex Wagner to Succeed Rachel Maddow at MSNBC
description: MSNBC’s president said Ms. Wagner’s experience covering politics would be crucial as the network prepared to cover the midterm elections.
content: MSNBC has named Alex Wagner to succeed Rachel Maddow as the weekday host of its 9 p.m. hour four days a week, turning to a political news veteran to fill one of the network’s most important time slots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Lysée’s Pastries Reflect Korea, France and New York
description: Eunji Lee’s new boutique, with a cafe and a luxe interior, is the fulfillment of a dream for the pastry chef.
content: Much of the décor is inspired by Korea, as are some ingredients (like buckwheat) and flavors, at Eunji Lee’s new pastry boutique and cafe, Lysée, the fulfillment of what she said was a dream. Ms. Lee, who was born in Busan, South Korea, studied pastry and worked in France before transferring her talents to Jungsik in New York. Her approach is reinforced by her French husband and partner, Matthieu Lobry, who she met working at Le Meurice in Paris. Among Ms. Lee’s specialties, for which she tried to combine Korean, French and New York influences, is a signature layered Lysée made with caramel, Korean brown rice cake, cream, mousse and pecans. A layered corn cake, shortbread cookies, kouign amann, and mini-loaves of carrot, yuzu and chocolate cake are some other pastries. Hand Hospitality is backing her venture; the name blends her surname with the French word for museum. The entry, paved with stones in a Korean fashion, leads to a cafe with a counter and a private nook. Upstairs the pastries are displayed in an airy space with walls flecked with mother-of-pearl and a counter for coffee, tea and Korean-inspired drinks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Genevieve Glatsky
title: Colombian Bullfight Stand Collapse Kills at Least 6
description: One child was reported dead when a spectator section collapsed at a bullfighting festival, and more than a hundred were reported injured.
content: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — At least six people were killed and more than a hundred injured Sunday when wooden spectator stands at a bullfighting festival collapsed, sending people running for safety.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Biden Irked by Democrats Who Won’t Take ‘Yes’ for an Answer on 2024
description: The White House is trying to tamp down speculation about plans to seek re-election, while aides say President Biden is bristling at the persistent questions.
content: WASHINGTON — Earlier this month, when Senator Bernie Sanders said he would not challenge President Biden in 2024, Mr. Biden was so relieved he invited his former rival to dinner at the White House the next night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chelsia Rose Marcius
title: Man Accused of Hitting Giuliani Faces Lesser Charges After Video Emerges
description: The case stems from an encounter at a Staten Island store where the former mayor was appearing on behalf of his son, a Republican candidate for governor.
content: A grocery store worker accused of assaulting Rudolph W. Giuliani at a Staten Island supermarket on Sunday had the charges against him reduced after the emergence of video footage that appeared to show him patting Mr. Giuliani on the back with an open palm rather than striking him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Vrentas
title: As N.F.L. Mulls Watson Case, an Accuser Adds Suit Against His Old Team
description: One of the 24 women who sued Watson for sexual misconduct claimed in a lawsuit filed Monday that the N.F.L. team enabled their star quarterback’s alleged behavior.
content: As the N.F.L.’s 15-month investigation into sexual misconduct claims against Deshaun Watson neared a resolution, one of his accusers filed suit Monday against Watson’s former team, the Houston Texans, alleging that the organization “turned a blind eye” to Watson’s behavior toward female massage therapists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay K. Varma
title: America May Soon Have Another Sexually Transmitted Infection
description: Monkeypox could exploit a big weakness in sexual health care.
content: Monkeypox infections are spreading rapidly in many countries, and the United States has, yet again, been caught flat-footed when confronted with another virus. Many problems with the Covid-19 response by the United States are being repeated: limited access to testing, contact tracing, vaccination and isolation support, and scant data from public health officials about how and where people are being infected. With infections currently concentrated among men who have sex with men, monkeypox has also exposed another critical vulnerability in the U.S. public health system: limited sexual health services in many parts of the country. That will make it more difficult to know how many monkeypox cases there are and to stop the virus from spreading.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines and Eliza Fawcett
title: Violent Threats to Election Workers Are Common. Prosecutions Are Not.
description: The Jan. 6 hearings laid bare how threats have terrified some election officials. But a federal pledge to address them has so far come up nearly empty.
content: WASHINGTON — “Do you feel safe? You shouldn’t.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Gonzalez
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Endangered’ and ‘The Man Who Fell to Earth’
description: A documentary about the dangers that journalists face airs on HBO. And the Showtime series starring Chiwetel Ejiofor wraps up its first season.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, June 27 to July 3. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: Alligator Fatally Attacks Man at the Edge of a South Carolina Pond
description: Such attacks are rare in the United States, typically occurring about once a year, but the latest one on Friday was the second in less than a month.
content: A man was killed on Friday after being dragged into a retention pond by an alligator near Myrtle Beach, S.C., the first such deadly attack in the state since 2020, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dorothy Wickham
title: Can You Blame Poor Countries Like Mine for Turning to China?
description: If the U.S. ignores the Pacific, China will step right in.
content: HONIARA, Solomon Islands — Judging from the American and Australian reactions, China’s push to raise its profile in the Pacific Ocean seems frightening indeed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Fahima Haque
title: America Before and After Roe
description: Three women lived through a time without Roe, and the early years after it. Their experiences working for abortion rights mimic the fight that continues today.
content: Catherine Starr was 17 when she attended her first demonstration to push for abortion rights outside City Hall in St. Louis. It was May 24, 1973. Just a few months earlier, the Supreme Court had ruled on Roe v. Wade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Caspian Kang
title: California’s Fight Against Homelessness Has Turned Desperate and Dangerous
description: A new psychiatric “court” plan for thousands of unhoused people puts their civil and human rights at risk.
content: If the homelessness crisis in California can offer any lessons to the rest of the country, it’s what politics looks like when a restless and beleaguered public places pressure on politicians to do something — anything — about a complex and seemingly intractable problem. The state has spent billions of dollars a year and tried a variety of solutions; none has put much of a dent in the public face of homelessness — the tent encampments of unhoused people that have sprung up throughout every major city in the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete McKenzie
title: Abroad, Jacinda Ardern Is a Star. At Home, She’s Losing Her Shine.
description: New problems in New Zealand like inflation and gang violence and old problems like unaffordable housing have sent her polling numbers to new lows as an election looms next year.
content: WELLINGTON, New Zealand — Abroad, Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern of New Zealand remains a leading liberal light. During a recent trip to the United States, she delivered the commencement address at Harvard, cracked jokes with Stephen Colbert and met in the Oval Office with President Biden. At each stop, she highlighted her successes in passing gun restrictions and handling the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: The Wild History of the Real ‘Only Murders’ Building
description: Viewers of the Hulu series know it as the Arconia, but the Upper West Side building has a name — and a dramatic story — of its own.
content: Fans of the Hulu series “Only Murders in the Building,” which returns for its second season this week, know the building at the center of the drama as the Arconia, where Steve Martin, Martin Short and Selena Gomez play an unlikely trio of residents who become amateur sleuths with a podcast. But the Renaissance-style apartment building on the Upper West Side of Manhattan is actually called the Belnord, and it has been making headlines for more than a century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: A Louisiana judge temporarily blocks enforcement of the state’s ‘trigger law.’
description: The judge’s order allows clinics to continue providing abortion services for now.
content: At least one of Louisiana’s three remaining abortion clinics said it would resume performing the procedure after a judge on Monday temporarily blocked enforcement of the state’s abortion “trigger laws.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan
title: Ocasio-Cortez wants two justices impeached for ‘lying under oath.’
description: The representative called for a House investigation into whether the justices, Neil Gorsuch and Brett M. Kavanaugh, were dishonest when discussing Roe v. Wade during confirmation hearings.
content: Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez is calling for a House investigation into whether two Supreme Court justices who voted to overturn Roe v. Wade should be impeached for lying at their confirmation hearings about their views of the landmark abortion-rights case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: U.S. Urges New Tactic to Curb Putin’s War Machine and Lower Fuel Prices
description: Group of 7 leaders meeting in Germany were receptive to a Biden administration plan to cap the price of Russian oil in world markets, limiting Kremlin revenue.
content: KRUN, Germany — Four months into Russia’s invasion, unprecedented Western economic retaliation and military aid to Ukraine have not curbed Vladimir V. Putin’s ability or apparent determination to wage war, leaving leaders of the world’s wealthiest democracies grasping for new ways to deter him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: Russia Misses Bond Deadline, Signaling Its First Default on Foreign Debt Since 1918
description: Economic sanctions that blocked bond payments have strengthened efforts to seal off Moscow from global markets.
content: Russia missed a deadline for making bond payments on Sunday, a move signaling its first default on international debt in more than a century, after Western sanctions thwarted the government’s efforts to pay foreign investors. The lapse adds to efforts to seal Moscow off from global capital markets for years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater and Maggie Haberman
title: Jan. 6 Panel Abruptly Sets Tuesday Hearing on ‘Recently Obtained Evidence’
description: The committee, which had planned at least two additional hearings next month, had not been scheduled to meet this week.
content: The House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol on Monday abruptly scheduled a hearing for Tuesday afternoon to hear what the panel called “recently obtained evidence” and take witness testimony, a surprise move that touched off a wave of speculation about a potential explosive revelation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rich Juzwiak
title: Beyoncé’s ‘Break My Soul’ and the Long Tail of ‘Show Me Love’
description: The ubiquitous 1992 remix of Robin S.’s song has endured in samples and covers. Its writers’ names appeared in the credits for Beyoncé’s track, were quickly removed and then restored again.
content: The intro is unmistakable for anyone who’s been on a dance floor in the last three decades. A grinding synth line and tactile thump give way to the instrumental pièce de résistance: an organ springy enough to conjure bouncing balls. Then, a human yowl cuts through with the urgency of a distress signal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $900,000 Homes in California
description: A two-bedroom bungalow in Oakland, a Craftsman home in Long Beach and a Spanish-style house in Ojai.
content: This house is in the Redwood Heights neighborhood, about 15 minutes by car from downtown Oakland and about 20 minutes from the heart of Berkeley. Some of the area’s most popular hiking spots are nearby, including the Sequoia Bayview Trailhead, the beginning of a hiking trail that winds through Dr. Aurelia Reinhardt Redwood Regional Park; and a trail in Leona Heights Park that passes waterfalls and redwood trees as it climbs to a peak with sweeping city views.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hugh Morris
title: William Herschel Is Famous for Science. What About His Music?
description: The accomplished astronomer was, one historian said, “the Einstein of his time.” But before he surveyed the sky, he was a prolific musician.
content: Within the four-square opening of William Herschel’s Symphony No. 8 is a phrase that sounds like one of the delicately reorchestrated pop songs in “Bridgerton.” The first violins play a goading, syncopated refrain as the harmony lurches underneath, slithering to a resolution before launching into grand second subject. It’s a standout moment, and an earworm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: ‘Chains’ Review: Drab Lives, but Dreaming of More
description: A young boarder’s plan to make a new life in Australia unsettles a staid British family in Elizabeth Baker’s 1909 play, revived by the Mint Theater Company.
content: On a Saturday afternoon in April, warm sunshine streams through the French doors of Lily and Charley Wilson’s rented London house, with its modest garden just outside. A comfortable home, it’s a bit of a stretch for their budget, so they have a boarder — Fred Tennant, a pleasant young clerk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: After a weekend of strikes, sirens bring anxiety even in Ukraine’s safest cities.
description: The dozens of the missiles launched by Russian forces into Ukraine over the weekend have raised anxiety in Lviv, even in the relative peace of the country’s northwest.
content: LVIV, Ukraine — The all-too-familiar blare of an air raid siren signaled rockets within striking distance of this city in western Ukraine on Monday afternoon. It was the fifth time in less than 48 hours.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Drake’s ‘Honestly, Nevermind’ Is His 11th No. 1 Album
description: The dance-oriented surprise release debuts with the equivalent of 204,000 sales — the streaming star’s lowest opening-week tally for a studio album.
content: A little over a week ago, Drake announced a surprise new album, “Honestly, Nevermind,” and released it online a few hours later. Just like clockwork, it has now gone to No. 1, becoming Drake’s 11th album to top the Billboard 200 chart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: What’s Next for California After Roe’s Reversal
description: About 10,600 more people are expected to come to California for abortion care each year, according to a U.C.L.A. report.
content: LOS ANGELES — Standing in front of a display of wire hangers at a protest downtown on Friday, hours after the Supreme Court struck down Roe v. Wade, Gloria Allred told the crowd about an illegal abortion that almost killed her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: At a Boarding School in Ukraine, Displaced Children Long for Home
description: Many left their parents behind when they were evacuated from the country’s east. Now they wrestle with the trauma of a conflict that has consumed much of their young lives.
content: LVIV, Ukraine — In the arched dining hall of a former boarding school in Lviv, Kamila Horbachova and other teenage girls set out dishes, as younger children scrambled into seats and then tucked into dinners handed out by the cafeteria staff.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Sherman
title: Ralph Fiennes to Star in Play About Robert Moses at the Shed
description: The production of “Straight Line Crazy,” by David Hare, will begin preview performances Oct. 18 and have a nine-week run.
content: “Straight Line Crazy,” the play by David Hare about the contentious urban planner Robert Moses, directed by Nicholas Hytner and Jamie Armitage, is coming to New York this fall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Shopping for Tablecloths
description: With so many appealing ones out there, it’s never been easier to dress your table up (or down).
content: A tablecloth can make an ugly table beautiful, hide a worn wooden top and immediately change the feeling of a dining space, indoors or out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: What’s Next for the Supreme Court?
description: Five Republican-appointed justices are ambitious and impatient to change American law.
content: My colleague Adam Liptak, who covers the Supreme Court, describes the five Republican-appointed justices besides Chief Justice John Roberts as “an impatient, ambitious majority.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: Spotting the Fault Lines in NATO’s United Front
description: The alliance is supporting Ukraine’s defense against Russia with money and arms, but its summit in Madrid this week will involve some difficult talks, including about where to put troops.
content: BRUSSELS — After the collapse of the Soviet Union, some asked whether NATO had any real reason to exist. But Russia’s invasion of Ukraine gave new urgency to NATO as a defensive alliance aimed at deterring Moscow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: Boeing 737 Max Flies Again, but Crash Victims’ Kin Say Risks Remain
description: Families are working with industry insiders to press for new safety precautions and a review of production practices for the aircraft.
content: It has been 18 months since Boeing’s 737 Max was allowed to start flying passengers again, but some of the families that lost loved ones in a pair of fatal crashes of the plane say they are still worried about its safety.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: The Former Electrical Engineer Leading Disney’s Streaming Strategy
description: Kareem Daniel has become one of the entertainment industry’s most powerful executives, exposing him to Hollywood’s slings and arrows.
content: Kareem Daniel was on crutches in the spring of 2002. He had broken his right ankle playing basketball. But Mr. Daniel had no time to convalesce: A self-imposed clock was ticking on his attempt to change careers — to abandon safe-and-steady electrical engineering, a field that his parents had pushed, for the wild-and-woolly movie business, which was his dream.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: The New (Cushy Seats) and the Familiar (Novak, Nerves) Mix at Wimbledon
description: One hundred years after the opening of Centre Court, it’s a season of change at the All England Club, what with the barring of Russian players and a new set of green doors.
content: WIMBLEDON, England — It is about tradition this year at Wimbledon on the 100th anniversary of Centre Court, but as the defending men’s singles champion Novak Djokovic walked back onto the grass on Monday to launch this year’s tournament, it was also about change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Sides With Coach Over Prayers at the 50-Yard Line
description: Joseph Kennedy, a former high school football coach in Bremerton, Wash., had a constitutional right to pray on the field after his team’s games, the justices ruled.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court ruled on Monday that a high school football coach had a constitutional right to pray at the 50-yard line after his team’s games, the latest step by the court in expanding the place of religion in public life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Fruit-Infused Vinegars at Home in Both Salads and Cocktails
description: Crushed tangerine, strawberry and blueberry varieties can provide sharpness to fresh berries and drinks, and a brightness to dishes.
content: Summer is the moment for this new collection of fruit-infused vinegars with a white wine vinegar base. They’re from a company selling products from Greece and elsewhere, and they provide versatility well beyond the salad bowl. Their uses include sharpening a mix of fresh berries or a cocktail, adding a new dimension to iced tea or a pan sauce for scallops or duck, and, with the tangerine flavor, bringing citric tang to ceviche. As for that summer salad, the tangerine or strawberry will contribute a touch of sweetness without the murk of balsamic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: The G7 ponders capping oil prices to deny Russia revenues. How would it work?
description: The goal is a way to tighten Russia’s finances while preventing big rises in oil prices. But it’s unclear if such a plan could succeed.
content: Leaders of the Group of 7 nations meeting in Germany, seeking a new way to throttle Russia’s finances while limiting the harm to Western economies, are discussing imposing a ceiling on the price paid for Russian oil. Details of the plan are still being discussed, but the idea is to limit how much Russia can earn from the oil it sells while still keeping markets well supplied.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri and Adeel Hassan
title: Alameda County, Calif., home to Oakland, drops its indoor mask mandate after three weeks.
description: Daily coronavirus case rates in the county are falling, and while the number of residents hospitalized remains high, daily new admissions have stabilized, health officials said.
content: Less than a month after instituting a mask mandate for most indoor settings, health officials for Alameda County, the San Francisco Bay Area’s second-most populous county, lifted the order, citing improving conditions in a news release.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Glorioso
title: Florida health care providers urge a judge to block the state’s new abortion ban.
description: They argued that a ban on abortion after 15 weeks of pregnancy would violate the state constitution.
content: TALLAHASSEE, Fla. — Health care providers argued before a Florida judge on Monday that the state’s new ban on abortion after 15 weeks of pregnancy violates the state constitution, and urged the court to block its enforcement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Suhasini Raj and Emily Schmall
title: Europe and the U.S. court India to join efforts to punish Russia.
description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India has maintained a neutral stance on the war.
content: As Ukraine’s allies seek to broaden the coalition of nations against Russia, the United States and Europe are working to persuade India to abandon its neutral stance in the war in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: Credit Suisse is fined for helping a Bulgarian drug ring launder money, a court said.
description: The bank, which has been struggling with losses and management turmoil, said it would appeal the decision by a Swiss court.
content: Credit Suisse must pay fines and compensation of 21 million Swiss francs, or $22 million, for lax controls that allowed an employee of the bank to help a Bulgarian drug ring launder money, Switzerland’s Federal Criminal Court said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: A Rhode Island candidate was charged after a video showed him punching an opponent at an abortion protest.
description: Jeann Lugo, a Republican and off-duty police officer, was suspended by the Providence Police Department after striking Jennifer Rourke, a Democrat, the authorities said.
content: Soon after a video appeared to capture a Republican State Senate candidate and off-duty police officer punching his Democratic opponent, a woman, at an abortion protest in Rhode Island, he was arrested and charged — and he withdrew from the race.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Lynsea Garrison, Diana Nguyen, Rob Szypko, Marc Georges, Mike Benoist, Marion Lozano, Elisheba Ittoop, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
title: Inside Four Abortion Clinics the Day Roe Ended
description: We hear from clinic doctors and staff members about what Friday was like for them.
content: This episode contains strong language and mentions sexual assault.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Yokhin
title: A Soccer Team’s Success Puts Its Small Arab Village on the Map
description: Established in 2016, Maccabi Bnei Reineh is the talk of Israel’s top division after completing a quick rise. Its founders say its presence represents something far more important.
content: REINEH, Israel — Jamil Bsoul is smiling. The mayor has clearly delivered this line before. But after all that his community’s soccer club has achieved, and in such a short time, that is what makes it fun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Pearson
title: New Guidelines Encourage Breastfeeding Longer, but Call for More Parental Support
description: The American Academy of Pediatrics is urging doctors to have “nonjudgmental conversations” with families about their feeding choices.
content: The American Academy of Pediatrics issued a policy statement Monday that extends the period of time for which breastfeeding is recommended to two years or more, but that also acknowledges the obstacles that stand in parents’ way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Vivian Giang, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni, Jenny Gross and Anna Schaverien
title: Elon Musk Fuels Record C.E.O. Paydays
description: A risky compensation plan at Tesla paid off and laid the groundwork that has pushed other executives’ compensation sky high.
content: In 2018, Elon Musk unveiled a groundbreaking compensation plan that was composed entirely of an enormous stock grant tied to Tesla’s performance. The plan linked his compensation to the future value of Tesla and the electric vehicle company’s ability to hit hugely ambitious targets for sales and operating profit. The gamble seems to have paid off: Musk has so far received shares for the award worth just over $60 billion. But it’s not only Musk that has profited: Compensation experts say they see the influence of Mr. Musk’s deal everywhere.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kris Rhim
title: Four Races From the U.S. Track and Field Championships Worth Watching Again
description: Sha’Carri Richardson did not qualify for the world championships, Sydney McLaughlin bests her own world record and a new rivalry heats up.
content: Stars falling short, a broken world record, and a brewing rivalry highlighted the four-day U.S. outdoor track and field championships in Eugene, Ore., over the weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priya Krishna
title: In Tulsa, a Burmese Cooking Tradition Takes the Spotlight
description: The food of the Zomi people of Myanmar isn’t easy to find in America, even in this city so welcoming to refugees. But this weekend it will move front and center.
content: TULSA, Okla. — The electrifying flavors of bawngsa kan — beef fried with generous amounts of tamarind, ginger and chiles — are easy to love. But finding the dish in an American restaurant is a challenge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: CRISPR, 10 Years On: Learning to Rewrite the Code of Life
description: The gene-editing technology has led to innovations in medicine, evolution and agriculture — and raised profound ethical questions about altering human DNA.
content: Ten years ago this week, Jennifer Doudna and her colleagues published the results of a test-tube experiment on bacterial genes. When the study came out in the journal Science on June 28, 2012, it did not make headline news. In fact, over the next few weeks, it did not make any news at all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein
title: Trump’s social network deal is under grand jury scrutiny.
description: A federal grand jury in Manhattan has issued subpoenas regarding the merger, which is also under investigation by financial regulators.
content: The public listing of former President Donald J. Trump’s social media company took a fresh blow on Monday when the cash-rich shell company merging with Mr. Trump’s company disclosed in a regulatory filing that a federal grand jury in New York recently issued subpoenas to the company and its directors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Just Add Tonic to This Apple Vodka From New York
description: Upstate Vodka, 80 proof with a fittingly fruity aroma, is made at Sauvage Distillery in Charlotteville, N.Y.
content: Apples, a major New York State crop, can be macerated, fermented and distilled into an apple vodka. Upstate Vodka is made at Sauvage Distillery in Charlotteville, N.Y., west of Albany, with the distillers Jamie Terk, and Ken Wortz, whose own distillery became Sauvage, in charge. The property has apple trees but also buys fruit, including Cortland, Kingston Black and Spy Gold varieties, from local orchards. The resulting spirit, 80 proof, has a lightly fruity aroma, is smooth on the palate, makes a commendable V&T and works well in cocktails. It’s kosher and gluten free, and each bottle is dated and numbered.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins, Ivan Nechepurenko, Megan Specia and Dan Bilefsky
title: A missile strike hits a crowded shopping center in central Ukraine.
description: Videos of the site, near the railway station in the central city of Kremenchuk, showed a fire raging as emergency workers frantically attempted to extinguish the flames.
content: KREMENCHUK, Ukraine — Hundreds of people were out shopping, chatting and meeting with friends in a shopping mall in central Ukraine on Monday, a rare moment of normalcy amid the horror of war. Then a Russian missile struck.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg and Julie Creswell
title: Facing a surge in demand, retailers limit emergency contraceptive purchases and deliveries.
description: CVS temporarily set a three-pack purchase limit to ensure “consistent supply on store shelves,” and Walgreens said it was pausing deliveries.
content: As people bought up Plan B and other emergency contraceptive pills after the Supreme Court’s decision overturning Roe v. Wade on Friday, at least two major pharmacies put limits on purchases or deliveries of the pills, which typically cost $10 to $50.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Hess
title: When an Abortion Story Is Told as a Caper, Thriller or Farce
description: As Roe falls, new works including a documentary, a feature film and a comedy show disrupt the taboos and clichés around abortion.
content: In 1969, when abortion was illegal in Illinois, an underground operation arose in Chicago. Officially called the Abortion Counseling Service of Women’s Liberation, it became known as the Jane network, because women seeking abortions were told to call a number and “ask for Jane.” As I watched “The Janes,” an HBO documentary about the service, I was struck by the buoyancy of the story. Though the women behind Jane were working under stress to provide secretive abortions to desperate and terrified women, a kicky sensibility pervades the film. There are weed jokes and anti-surveillance shenanigans and a soundtrack fit for a mod spy movie. As the Janes evade the church, the Mafia and the police to facilitate around 11,000 clandestine abortions, they emerge from anonymity as the stars of a new genre: the abortion caper.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: How a Tennis Nerd Gave Serena and Venus Williams a New Lease on the Game
description: Eric Hechtman, a club professional from Miami, has signed on to help two champions chase success far beyond the usual finish line of a tennis career.
content: WIMBLEDON, England — Already coaching one American tennis icon, Eric Hechtman added another: logging the extra miles and the extra hours to try to help both Venus and Serena Williams get the most out of however many matches or seasons they have left.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Russian Court Says Brittney Griner’s Trial Will Begin on Friday
description: Ms. Griner, a seven-time W.N.B.A. all-star, has been in custody since February.
content: A Russian court said the trial for the U.S. basketball star Brittney Griner will begin on Friday and she will remain in custody until it ends, her lawyer, Aleksandr Boikov, said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: Companies Scramble to Work Out Policies Related to Employee Abortions
description: Some have offered to cover travel and other expenses for employees, and are working to ease worker fears about safety and confidentiality.
content: There is no clear blueprint for corporate engagement on abortion. After numerous companies came forward to announce that they would cover travel expenses for their employees to get abortions, executives have had to move swiftly to both sort out the mechanics of those policies and explain them to a work force concerned about confidentiality and safety.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: California lawmakers place a constitutional amendment protecting abortion rights on the fall ballot.
description: The amendment would explicitly protect reproductive rights in the state.
content: SACRAMENTO — California state lawmakers on Monday put a state constitutional amendment on the ballot that would explicitly protect reproductive rights, moving swiftly on the first business day after the Supreme Court reversed Roe v. Wade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yana Dlugy
title: New Ways to Try to Punish Russia
description: G7 leaders are considering putting price caps on Russian oil.
content: Hello. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins
title: After Monday’s mall airstrike, shocked residents grapple with the destruction, the dead and the missing.
description: “The worst thing is that this is a shopping mall,” said a town official. “Any of us could have been here.”
content: KREMENCHUK, Ukraine — Late into the evening on Monday night, the Amstar shopping mall was still smoking as hundreds of firefighters and emergency workers sought to clear away the rubble.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler and Mitch Smith
title: Abortion Rights Groups Take Up the Fight in the States
description: Abortion rights advocates filed lawsuits to halt or delay bans on abortion in some states, with judges in Louisiana and Utah temporarily blocking new laws.
content: SACRAMENTO — The battle over abortion shifted to the states on Monday as a weekend of furious protest and prayerful thanksgiving in the wake of the Supreme Court’s Roe v. Wade reversal gave way to a coast-to-coast wave of lawsuits, legislation and pitched political fights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oliver Whang
title: The Many Uses of CRISPR: Scientists Tell All
description: What do infectious diseases, T-cells, tomatoes, heart failure, sickle cell anemia and sorghum harvests have in common?
content: Smartphones, superglue, electric cars, video chat. When does the wonder of a new technology wear off? When you get so used to its presence that you don’t think of it anymore? When something newer and better comes along? When you forget how things were before?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Screen Kings of Rock ’n’ Roll: The Best and Worst Actors to Play Elvis
description: In honor of Austin Butler’s performance in the Baz Luhrmann biopic, we ranked 10 of the best — and worst — Presleys to grace the silver screen.
content: Kurt Russell had the hip swivel down cold. Val Kilmer nailed the sincere, soulful voice. And Michael Shannon … well, the credits identified him as Elvis Presley, so that was the character he must have been playing in “Elvis & Nixon,” right?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: What is the difference between Plan B and the abortion pill?
description: Both medications come in pill form and are often confused for each other. Here’s how they differ.
content: In the wake of the Supreme Court overturning Roe v. Wade, some women are evaluating their options for reproductive health care. Many are stocking up on morning-after pills, which are used to prevent a pregnancy from occurring within days after unprotected sex; while others are wondering how the ruling will affect their access to abortion pills, which can be used to terminate early pregnancies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Your Tuesday Briefing: G7 Leaders Meet in Germany
description: Also, Russia defaults on its debt and New Zealand’s prime minister loses support at home.
content: At a summit in the mountains of Germany, leaders of the Group of 7 nations embraced an aggressive but untried plan to manipulate the price of oil, the largest commodity market in the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Kandell
title: Leonardo Del Vecchio Dies at 87; Transformed Eyeglass Industry
description: He merged eyewear with fashion, turning a quotidian necessity into high style. He rose from poverty to become one of the world’s wealthiest men.
content: Leonardo Del Vecchio, the Italian multibillionaire who rose from Dickensian poverty to build a globe-straddling behemoth that helped transform the stodgy, fragmented eyeglass industry into a fashion-oriented business, died on Monday in Milan. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Sides With Doctors Accused of Running Pill Mills
description: In a unanimous ruling, the justices ordered federal appeals courts to reconsider the cases of two doctors convicted of violating the Controlled Substances Act.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday sided with two doctors convicted of illegally dispensing drugs without a legitimate medical purpose.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: Lessons From the Terrible Triumph of the Anti-Abortion Movement
description: What pro-choice activists can learn from their enemies.
content: In the grief-choked days since the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, I’ve been haunted by a moment from the new documentary “Battleground.” Much of the film, which recently premiered at the Tribeca Film Festival, follows female leaders of the anti-abortion movement, including Marjorie Dannenfelser, president of Susan B. Anthony Pro-Life America, and Kristan Hawkins, president of Students for Life of America. These aren’t the people regularly standing outside of abortion clinics harassing patients. They are, rather, savvy lobbyists and organizers, and the documentary is in part a window into how they won.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: In the Stanley Cup, He Was Where He Wanted to Be: ‘In the Thick of It’
description: Colorado’s Nazem Kadri returned from an injury to win the Stanley Cup and a measure of redemption after having been criticized as being a liability in the playoffs.
content: TAMPA, Fla. — The pain in Nazem Kadri’s thumb, operated on earlier this month, was so severe that he could not lace up his skates for the last three games of the Stanley Cup finals. Just gripping his stick was a chore, but he did it well enough to score one of the defining goals of a terrific series, the overtime winner in Game 4.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing and Federico Borella
title: Icons of Italian Automotive Style Struggle to Go Electric
description: Ferrari and Lamborghini are trying to design battery-powered cars that inspire the same devotion as their costly internal combustion models.
content: SANT’AGATA BOLOGNESE, Italy — The boys spilling out of a grade school in an Italian village went silent as the Lamborghini approached, its throaty 12-cylinder engine trumpeting its presence. Then, as the wedge-shaped beast rumbled by the schoolyard, they broke into cheers, pumping their fists and leaping into the air.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Cohen
title: What the ban on Russia’s gold imports means for its increasingly isolated economy.
description: The move by the United States, Britain and others builds on steps to cut off Russia from the international financial system.
content: The decision over the weekend to ban the purchase of newly mined and refined gold from Russia is the latest effort by the United States, Britain and their allies to notch up the wave of sanctions concentrated on Russia in response to its four-month-old invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: The Supreme Court’s Fighting Words
description: Dobbs and Bruen reveal the sweeping terribleness of the current court’s reasoning.
content: Bret Stephens: Hi, Gail. We’ve had two monumental Supreme Court decisions over the last week, on guns and abortion. Maybe it isn’t a fair question, but which of them scares, dismays, enrages or makes you want to bang your head against the wall more?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell
title: A Couple’s Long Journey in the Anti-Abortion Movement
description: As the fall of Roe v. Wade rocked the country, Carrie and Roger Severino celebrated the realization of decades of work that has been complicated in recent years by health challenges.
content: In the early 2000s, Harvard Right to Life, the university’s chapter of a student organization that opposes abortion, had T-shirts made that say, “Working for the Class of ’25” on the back. Another shirt from that era reads: “Smile! Your mom chose life.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Cancellations of Procedures Alarm Patients
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, June 27, 2022.
content: “When I went to bed, I had my appointment and everything was set, and then today it’s like pre-1973.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adèle Cordonnier
title: A News Revolution for Young People Takes Root in France
description: YouTubers in the country are finding success by delivering political content to an audience that tends to shun traditional media.
content: PARIS — At first glance, the office looks like that of any video production start-up — modern furniture, a video game console, a Buzz Lightyear action figure and nobody who looks over 30. But this bustling office in a hip neighborhood of Paris is in fact one of France’s most successful new newsrooms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: They Found Two New Craters on the Moon and Discovered a New Mystery
description: Tediously searching through imagery from a NASA spacecraft, researchers found where a discarded stage of a forgotten rocket crashed in March. But other questions remain.
content: After months of scrutinizing photographs of the lunar surface, scientists have finally found the crash site of a forgotten rocket stage that struck the far side of the moon in March.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: Lithuania blames Russia for cyberattacks, citing threats over cargo restrictions.
description: Hackers have struck dozens of Lithuanian government and private organizations, according to a Lithuanian official.
content: Just days after Moscow threatened retaliation against Lithuania for placing restrictions on cargo traffic to the isolated Russian territory of Kaliningrad, computer hackers “linked to the Russian state” attacked dozens of Lithuanian government and private organizations, the Baltic nation’s deputy defense minister said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Waffle Cone Pie Crusts From the Inventive Christina Tosi
description: This pie is filled with chocolate brownie, frozen vanilla pudding and peanuts, evoking the classic drumstick cone.
content: She made Cereal Milk soft-serve and the Compost Cookie household names, and now the ever-inventive Christina Tosi has turned waffle cones into crunchy pie crust. The filling builds with a layer of chocolate brownie topped with vanilla pudding flavored like vanilla ice cream, finished with a hard chocolate-peanut shell and peanut clusters, all evoking the classic drumstick cone for an excellent summer treat. The whole pie ($53) and slices ($7) are sold at Milk Bar bakeries; the pies are available for nationwide delivery. It is shipped frozen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: As Wimbledon Begins, an Era of Sports Free of Bans and Boycotts Ends
description: For decades, sports has avoided punishing athletes for the actions of their countries. Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has put an end to that.
content: LONDON — For roughly three decades, making sure athletes participated in the biggest events regardless of the world’s never-ending military and political battles has been a nearly sacrosanct tenet of international sports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Global Food Crisis Tests Western Resolve to Retain Russia Sanctions
description: With a food shortage threatening to create widespread famine, Western countries face a tough choice as sanctions exacerbate the problem.
content: WASHINGTON — In Yemen, the price of bread surged 35 percent the week Russia invaded Ukraine. Wheat mills lacking grain in Lebanon have halted operations in recent months, forcing bakeries to shutter. And in Kenya, cooking oil is scarce.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bailey
title: Stream These 9 Movies and Shows Before They Leave Netflix in July
description: Subscribers in the United States will lose a classic ’90s rom-com among other delightful titles. Watch these while you can.
content: One of the funniest sitcoms on Netflix makes its exit for U.S. subscribers at the end of July. If that’s not cause enough for distress, the streamer is also jettisoning a handful of delightful coming-of-age movies, a classic ’90s rom-com and one of the most influential movies of the 2010s. Watch them while you can. (Dates reflect the final day a title is available.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Zernike
title: In Florida, California and Beyond: Both Sides Mobilize Over Abortion
description: On Monday, plaintiffs will ask a judge to block Florida’s law banning abortion after 15 weeks of pregnancy. It is set to take effect on Friday.
content: Follow our live updates on abortion news and the Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Abortion Ruling Casts Shadow on Pride Festivities
description: The annual Pride parade returned to the streets of Manhattan, but this year the mood was one of protest.
content: Good morning. It’s Monday. We’ll look at the sense of urgency that the Supreme Court’s abortion ruling added to the annual gay pride parade. We’ll also get a look at a sculpture by Jean Dubuffet that was all but forgotten for decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: How Rosé Became a Lifestyle
description: Joey Wölffer of Wölffer Estate has turned pink wine into a symbol of the Hamptons life that she epitomizes.
content: “I hate the word ‘trend,’” said Joey Wölffer, an owner of the Hamptons winery Wölffer Estate, known for its rosé. It is a surprising statement from someone who makes one of the most ubiquitous beverages in the Hamptons and beyond. But Ms. Wölffer has been at it for a while.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Civilians should immediately evacuate a Ukrainian city that is under fire, a regional official warned.
description: Residents of Lysychansk, across the river from a city that fell to Russian control last week, should leave over “the real threat to life and health,” the region’s military governor said.
content: LVIV, Ukraine — Civilians should immediately leave the Ukrainian city of Lysychansk, the region’s governor said on Monday — an indication of the gathering pace of the Russian onslaught in the Donbas region of eastern Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roberta Smith
title: Sam Gilliam, Abstract Artist of Drape Paintings, Dies at 88
description: A brilliant colorist, he hung his canvases from ceilings in great curves and loops, or pinned them, gathered, to walls, taking his medium into three dimensions.
content: Sam Gilliam, a pioneering abstract painter best known for his lusciously stained Drape paintings, which took his medium more fully into three-dimensions than any other artist of his generation, died on Saturday at his home in Washington. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser
title: Maxwell Faces Sentencing Tuesday as Epstein’s Confidante and Enabler
description: Defense lawyers have argued that Ghislaine Maxwell became the primary target in the sex-abuse case only after Jeffrey Epstein killed himself.
content: Almost exactly two years after Ghislaine Maxwell was arrested in New Hampshire and brought to New York to face charges that she conspired with Jeffrey Epstein to recruit, groom and abuse underage girls, she is to be sentenced on Tuesday in Manhattan federal court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Poisonous Gas Leak in Jordan Kills at Least 10 People
description: Public security officials said a gas tanker sprung a leak while being transported, and video showed a tanker being dropped as it was moved and emitting a large cloud of yellow smoke.
content: AMMAN, Jordan — A poisonous gas leak in Jordan’s southern port city of Aqaba on Monday killed at least 10 people and injured some 250, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Reyburn
title: A Grand Old Art Fair Returns, to a World That Has Changed
description: At TEFAF Maastricht, a sense of resumed normalcy was tempered by an awareness that the pandemic has profoundly altered the business of selling centuries-old art.
content: MAASTRICHT, the Netherlands — The European Fine Art Fair, known as TEFAF, was the international art market’s first major casualty of the coronavirus pandemic. It’s also been one of the last to return to relative normalcy.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Virginia Primary Election Results
description: See full results and maps from the Virginia primary elections.
content: See full results and maps from the Virginia primary elections.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Amtrak Train Derails in Missouri, Killing at Least 3

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: Spectator Stand at Colombian Bullfight Collapses, Killing at Least 6
description: At least six people were killed and more than a hundred were reported injured when a wooden spectator section collapsed at a bullfighting festival in Colombia.
content: At least six people were killed and more than a hundred were reported injured when a wooden spectator section collapsed at a bullfighting festival in Colombia.

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: What to Cook Right Now
description: Lean into longer recipes (if you dare), or roast canned or frozen artichokes for a flavorful lemon spaghetti.
content: Hello there. By now you’ve heard from Melissa Clark, Priya Krishna and Genevieve Ko instead of Sam Sifton, who’s been traveling. (It takes a village to cover for Sam.) And now, you’ve got me. I’m the Food and Cooking editor of The New York Times, and I’m tickled to be your host on this summer Monday morning.
source.name: The New York Times
